articles.content:
# The Village Where Draft-Age Men Have Mostly Vanished

Published: 2025-11-10T10:38:43-05:00

Draft officers picked Ivan up at a traffic stop and dropped him off at a training base, but he went absent without leave from the army after three days. Since then, he has been hiding at home in Vylkove, a small town in southernmost Ukraine, rarely stepping outside.

Almost four years after the full-scale Russian invasion, Ukraine faces the twin challenges of not having enough troops and men avoiding military service. Many men of draft age, 25 to 60, have broken the law that prohibits most of them from leaving the country, while others play a cat-and-mouse game with conscription officers or just hunker down at home.

The unique geography and history of Vylkove, a run-down Danube River fishing port, have made it an exaggerated version of Ukraine in miniature, where draft-age men have all but vanished.

“Who’s left?” asked Ivan, 42, speaking on the condition that his last name be withheld for his safety. “Women, the elderly and men who try not to go out unnecessarily.”

National identity is not so deeply rooted in this region, which has changed hands repeatedly between countries, and enthusiasm for the war is unusually low here, though plenty of men have gone to fight.

Romania beckons, visible just across the Danube, and Moldova is close by, so escape is unusually enticing. Many men have gone that route, but others have died trying or been caught. Vylkove is hemmed in by rivers, marshes and roadblocks, making flight difficult and dangerous enough to convince men like Ivan that they are better off just hiding, dreading a knock on the door.

In contrast, Vylkove’s women come and go freely, and for some, the changes have been liberating, opening up jobs that had been closed to them.

The draft dragnet is especially intense along Ukraine’s borders. Vylkove has canals for streets — it is sometimes called, with considerable generosity, the Venice of Ukraine — and border guard boats patrol the waterways.

Men have tried to cross the river to Romania in boats, diving equipment, even homemade rafts of five-liter plastic bottles.

“Even well-prepared people got caught in currents,” and are swept away, said Oleh Mukomela, a major in the border guard service. The service estimates that, nationwide, at least 70 men have drowned or died in the woods and marshes while trying to escape Ukraine.

Just one road leads out of Vylkove, and it has border guard roadblocks. Farther along, the main highway providing access to the rest of the country crosses into Moldova, and then back into Ukraine, passing through border posts. There was another major road, leading to Odesa, until Russian bombardment damaged a bridge on it.

Mariners are permitted to leave Ukraine for work on ships, but many have set sail and not returned. Their wives and children who stayed behind now visit them in neighboring countries between sea voyages.

Draft dodgers who can make their way around checkpoints often abandon their cars and dash on foot through trees and vegetable gardens to Moldova. Criminal networks smuggle people out of the country illegally, for a steep price.

Ukrainian commanders and military experts say the troop shortage has opened gaps of hundreds of yards between manned frontline positions, enabling Russian advances. Hundreds of thousands of Ukrainian troops have been killed, wounded or captured, or are missing.

Amid such sacrifice, Ukrainians are generally not sympathetic to those who avoid service. Prosecutors say they have opened 290,000 cases for desertion or for being absent without leave.

But the region once known as Southern Bessarabia, which includes Vylkove, is different. Much of the population is Russian-speaking, descended from “Old Believers” who centuries ago rejected modernizing trends in the Russian Orthodox Church and settled here to escape persecution.

Since 1812, this area has been held by the Ottoman Empire, Russia, Moldavia, Romania, Russia again, Ukraine, Germany, Romania again, the Soviet Union, Romania a third time, the Soviet Union again and then Ukraine again. The shifting national allegiance has left a deep imprint on how residents view the government and their duty to serve, said Volodymyr Poltorak, historian at the Oriental Institute of the Czech Academy of Sciences.

“Any form of authority is met with distrust,” he said. “In a way, they are anarchists.”

Of the nearly 8,000 residents of Vylkove when the full-scale war began, only about 5,000 remain — though with so many people hiding, estimates are tricky. Everyone knows someone who left.

“I really miss him,” said Halyna Silarina, 55, of a sailor friend who left when the war started.

Pouring homemade wine into their glasses, her husband, Anatoliy Silarin, 61, toasted to the return of their former lives. “Maybe this place used to be Venice,” he said. “Now who knows what it is.”

“The world has shrunk completely,” said one male resident who is nearly 60 but still draft-eligible. He requested anonymity to avoid being caught. About half the remaining men of draft age do not leave their houses at all, he said.

As to feeling trapped,  he said it was important not to dwell on it. He busied himself this year by picking the figs from his tree as they ripened each day, and made fig jam, he said.

With men missing, women adopted traditionally male jobs, including fishing, a mainstay of the town’s economy. From around 700 fishermen, Vylkove is down to only 70, most of them older than 60, according to the mayor, Matviy Ivanov.

At the city hall, Mr. Ivanov said, all the other employees are women. “I’m the only man left.” Or, at least, the only one visible.

“It’s women everywhere” in town now, he said. “They enjoy it, they’ve taken over every sector, and now they’re in charge.”

Two sisters, Antonina Bilovolenko, 67, and Klavdiia Moskvichova, 63, are delighted to have become employees of a fishing company, even if it is hard work.

They always loved fishing but before the war they couldn’t get jobs doing it, so they mostly tended gardens instead. But with labor in short supply, companies have become more open to hiring women. Every day now, they put on warm clothes, prepare their nets, and sail out to catch fish.

“We love it, love it above all jobs,” Ms. Moskvichova said.

Ms. Bilovolenko added, “You go out on the water and forget everything, the what and the how.”

Their brother, Anatoliy Unharov, 66, used to work for the same company and envies his sisters still being out on the water. “Not all men can match them when it comes to fishing,” he said.

For other women, the changes are more a burden than an opportunity.

Olha, 50, said she struggled with the physical labor she does for a company that harvests reeds for export. Her husband was detained by draft officers and put into the army, she said, so she took over his job. She declined to give her surname, fearing it could help expose men in hiding.

The work was hard, she said, adding that her husband used to do it.

War has hit the area’s tourism business hard. One local company, Pelican, which plays on the Venice parallel, had 50 employees before the war. Now there are 20, mainly women and older people, said the owner, Mykhailo Zhmud, who at 66 is too old to draft.

His mechanic is now hiding at home, he said. “When I call and ask him to look at the boat, he says, ‘Let me first check if there are draft officers in town.’”

Evelina Riabenko contributed reporting from Kyiv, Ukraine.

articles.title: Anti-Corruption Agencies Double Down Despite Pressure From Zelensky
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Ukrainian anti-corruption agencies, including the National Anti-Corruption Bureau and the Special Anticorruption Prosecutor, announced a major investigation into a corruption scheme involving state-owned nuclear energy company Energoatom. The probe, dubbed 'Midas,' uncovered 1,000 hours of audio recordings over 15 months and identified a high-level criminal organization that allegedly pressured contractors to pay kickbacks of up to 15%. Key figures include a former energy minister adviser, an Energoatom security executive, money launderers, and businessman Timur Mindich, who is linked to Zelensky and reportedly fled after a raid on his home. Despite President Volodymyr Zelensky's earlier efforts to weaken the agencies, public pressure and youth protests led to a reversal, allowing the investigations to continue. The findings coincide with a significant Russian attack on Ukraine’s power grid and raise concerns about energy security and governance integrity. The Ukraine Facility Platform notes that increased government control over energy post-2022 has not reduced corruption. The investigation has sparked broader debate about political accountability and the role of anti-corruption institutions in a war-torn state.
keyTakeAways: The National Anti-Corruption Bureau and the Special Anticorruption Prosecutor uncovered a major corruption scheme involving kickbacks of up to 15% from contractors of Energoatom, Ukraine’s state-owned nuclear energy company.

The investigation, named 'Midas,' includes 1,000 hours of audio recordings compiled over 15 months and documents the activities of a 'high-level criminal organization' targeting strategic state enterprises.

The agencies conducted over 70 searches and identified key figures including a former adviser to the minister of energy, the executive director for physical protection at Energoatom, four money laundering team members, and a 'businessman well known in the media' accused of leading the illicit enterprise.
The head of Energoatom resigned in August under unclear circumstances, and a top official of an Energoatom subsidiary was arrested on bribery allegations.

President Volodymyr Zelensky previously attempted to defang anti-corruption agencies in July, but public pressure from youth demonstrators led him to back down, allowing the agencies to continue investigations.
The investigation coincided with a major Russian attack on Ukraine’s power grid, including nuclear power substations, raising concerns about energy security amid corruption.
A recent report by the Ukraine Facility Platform found that post-2022 government expansion of control over energy sectors did not reduce corruption and may have even worsened it.

Anti-corruption investigator Yaroslav Zhelezniak, who was arrested in July on what supporters call politically motivated charges, provided material to the agencies, which was integrated into the 'Midas' investigation.
The agencies raided the home of businessman Timur Mindich, a half-owner of a television studio linked to Zelensky, who fled the country hours later. The company Fire Point denies ties to Mindich.
The agencies did not name individuals directly, but their allegations suggest significant links between political figures, state-owned enterprises, and illicit financial flows.

articles.content:
# Anti-Corruption Agencies Double Down Despite Pressure From Zelensky

Published: 2025-11-10T10:15:37-05:00

The main anti-corruption agencies in Ukraine announced on Monday that they had uncovered a major corruption scheme in which contractors of the state-owned nuclear energy company had been forced to pay hefty kickbacks.

The inquiry was announced by the National Anti-Corruption Bureau and the Special Anticorruption Prosecutor — agencies that President Volodymyr Zelensky tried to defang in July after they had investigated his close associates.

Mr. Zelensky, who was elected president in 2019, entered politics pledging to root out the graft that has long plagued Ukraine. But allegations of insider deals and corruption have continued during his administration, particularly in the energy sector.

Instead of backing off under pressure from Mr. Zelensky, the anti-corruption agencies seem to be doubling down on their scrutiny of the country’s leaders. In their investigation into the state-owned electricity provider, the agencies said they had compiled 1,000 hours of audio recordings over 15 months and had documented “the activities of a high-level criminal organization.”

Members of the organization had “built a large-scale corruption scheme to influence strategic state-sector enterprises,” in particular Energoatom, the government-owned nuclear company, the agencies said in a news release.

Oleksandr Abakumov, a top anti-corruption detective, said in a video on social media that the agencies had performed more than 70 searches in the investigation, which they are calling “Midas.” The agencies said they had uncovered corruption that included money laundering and illicit enrichment.

The announcement came as Ukraine struggled to recover from one of the most serious attacks on its power grid in years. Early on Saturday, Russian missiles and drones targeted the country’s energy and gas infrastructure, hitting at least 25 locations, including nuclear power substations.

Dmytro Lytvyn, an adviser to Mr. Zelensky, said on Monday that the president’s office supported any attempt to root out corruption in state-owned companies but could not comment on the investigation because all the details were not public.

Mr. Zelensky had earlier announced negotiations with Ukraine’s partners in Europe to get more funding and equipment for the country’s energy system.

Energoatom said it was fully cooperating with the investigation.

The news release by the anti-corruption agencies, and the slickly produced videos that followed, showed they were continuing to dig into suspected schemes after Mr. Zelensky reversed his legislative efforts to neuter the agencies in July. He backed down after young Ukrainians took to the streets, saying the country’s democracy must be protected.

The anti-corruption agencies said a recording released Monday was of government officials and businessmen on July 9 discussing the embezzlement of funds that were intended to protect the energy sector from shelling. It was impossible to verify the authenticity of the recording or to know for certain who was talking and what their words meant.

The agencies did not name those they were accusing of crimes. But in a YouTube video posted on Monday, the agencies said members of the criminal organization included a former adviser to the minister of energy, the executive director for physical protection and security at Energoatom, four members of a team responsible for money laundering, and “a businessman well known in the media” whom they accused of leading the illicit enterprise. The agencies added that contractors were pressured for kickbacks of up to 15 percent.

The head of Energoatom resigned in August under unclear circumstances. Last week, the anti-corruption agencies arrested a top official of an Energoatom subsidiary on bribery allegations.

A recent report by an independent Ukrainian think tank that focuses on energy said the government had rapidly expanded its control of the energy sector after Russia’s full-scale invasion in 2022.

“This shift has not reduced corruption; in many cases, corrupt practices have persisted or worsened,” said the think tank, the Ukraine Facility Platform, which did the report in July for the European Union.

When Mr. Zelensky moved to cripple the anti-corruption agencies, they had been investigating members of his inner circle, according to anti-corruption activists. Deputy Prime Minister Oleksiy Chernyshov was charged with corruption in June. And the businessman Timur Mindich, who is half-owner of a television studio started by Mr. Zelensky, is the subject of a large-scale investigation, according to the newspaper Ukrainska Pravda.

An anti-corruption investigator who was arrested in July on what his supporters call politically motivated charges had been involved in the investigation into Mr. Mindich, said Yaroslav Zhelezniak, an opposition member of Parliament.

On Monday afternoon, Mr. Zhelezniak said he had gathered material showing corruption in Energoatom and had given it to the anti-corruption agencies. He said some of it had been folded into the investigation announced Monday.

“I’m very happy that I was right,” Mr. Zhelezniak said, adding that he thought this was one of the biggest corruption scandals ever uncovered in Ukraine.

The National Anti-Corruption Bureau raided the home of Mr. Mindich on Monday, Ukrainska Pravda reported. Hours before, Mr. Mindich fled the country, it said. These developments could not be independently confirmed.

Another newspaper, The Kyiv Independent, reported in August that the anti-corruption agency was examining ties between Mr. Mindich and a weapons manufacturer, Fire Point. The company has denied business ties to Mr. Mindich.

Constant Méheut, Andrew E. Kramer and Oleksandra Mykolyshyn contributed reporting.

articles.title: Black Musical Theater, 200 Years and Running
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: This article explores the deep historical roots of Black musical theater in the United States, tracing its lineage from early 19th-century performances at the African Grove theater to major 20th-century productions like 'Shuffle Along,' 'In Dahomey,' and 'Porgy and Bess.' It emphasizes that Black musical theater began long before the 20th century, with artists like James Hewlett, Ira Aldridge, and the Hyers Sisters creating works for Black audiences and asserting cultural autonomy. Despite pervasive racism and the use of offensive stereotypes in minstrel shows and early musicals, Black performers organized through groups like The Frogs and the Clef Club to gain professional dignity and representation. Key artists such as Will Marion Cook, James Reese Europe, and Rosetta LeNoire made significant contributions to the genre, both in performance and in creating new forms. The article highlights how these early achievements laid the foundation for modern Black musicals like 'Hamilton' and 'The Lion King,' showing that the legacy of Black musical theater is not only a recent phenomenon but a centuries-long tradition of self-expression, innovation, and cultural resistance.
keyTakeAways: Black musical theater has a lineage stretching back to the early 1800s, with roots in the African Grove theater and performances by early Black artists like James Hewlett and Ira Aldridge.

The 1921 production of 'Shuffle Along' was a major breakthrough, being the first all-Black creative team to produce a successful Broadway musical with an all-Black cast and orchestra, and its hit song 'I’m Just Wild About Harry' became a national phenomenon.

Despite systemic racism, Black artists consistently worked to create their own forms of expression, such as in 'Clorindy,' 'In Dahomey,' and 'Abyssinia,' challenging stereotypes and asserting cultural autonomy.
Professional organizations like The Frogs (1908) and the Clef Club (1910) were instrumental in helping Black artists gain visibility, fair pay, and top billing in national entertainment circuits.
The legacy of Black musical theater is evident in modern works like 'Hamilton' and 'The Lion King,' which are seen as part of a broader lineage of Black contributions to American musical theater.

The concept of 'what Black people did for themselves' — as emphasized by George C. Wolfe — is central: Black artists created distinct styles and forms that, once developed, became foundational to American musical theater as a whole.

Even when Black musical works were influenced by or adapted from white-authored stories (e.g., 'Porgy and Bess'), they played a crucial role in shaping the genre and providing platforms for future generations of Black performers.
The 2016 revival of 'Shuffle Along' underscores the ongoing relevance of this history, as it reasserts the foundational role of Black musical theater in American culture.

namedEntities.name: George C. Wolfe
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Playwright and director
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is central to the article’s argument that Black musical theater should be understood not through the lens of racism, but through the achievements of Black artists in creating their own cultural forms.

namedEntities.name: Noble Sissle and Eubie Blake
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Songwriting team
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: They co-created 'Shuffle Along,' the first successful all-Black Broadway musical, which became a landmark in Black musical theater history.

namedEntities.name: Flournoy Miller and Aubrey Lyles
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Comedy team
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: They partnered with Sissle and Blake to form the creative team behind 'Shuffle Along,' contributing to its success and cultural impact.

namedEntities.name: Shuffle Along
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Musical theater production
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It premiered in 1921 and is considered a foundational work in Black musical theater, with an all-Black creative team and company, and its hit song 'I’m Just Wild About Harry' became a national phenomenon.

namedEntities.name: African Grove
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Theater in Greenwich Village
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It operated in the early 1820s and staged early Black performances, including an 1821 production of 'Richard III,' marking one of the earliest known instances of Black artists performing for Black audiences.

namedEntities.name: James Hewlett
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Actor and co-founder of African Grove
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He starred in the African Grove’s 1821 production of 'Richard III,' which was favorably reviewed by white newspapers and helped establish early Black performance in American theater.

namedEntities.name: Ira Aldridge
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Classical actor
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He became a prominent classical performer, especially in Europe, where he performed in roles like 'Othello,' demonstrating the limitations Black artists faced in mainstream white-dominated theater.

namedEntities.name: Anna Madah Hyers and Emma Louise Hyers
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Sisters and singers
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: They founded a touring theater company after the Civil War, with their 1876 show 'Out of Bondage' marking one of the earliest examples of American musical theater as a distinct form.

namedEntities.name: Out of Bondage
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Musical drama
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The first production by the Hyers sisters, it addressed the themes of slavery and emancipation and is considered a milestone in the emergence of American musical theater.

namedEntities.name: The Underground Railway
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Musical production by Hyers
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: One of the later productions by the Hyers sisters, it continued their exploration of African American experiences and themes of freedom.

namedEntities.name: Uncle Tom’s Cabin
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Musical production by Hyers
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Another of the Hyers sisters’ productions, it reflects the cultural context of post-Civil War America and the use of familiar stories to explore Black experiences.

namedEntities.name: Minstrel shows
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Entertainment genre
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: These shows used offensive racial stereotypes and blackface, often featuring Black performers in demeaning roles, and were a dominant form of entertainment that Black artists sometimes participated in despite their own efforts to create dignity and autonomy.

namedEntities.name: Carry Me Back to Old Virginny
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Song
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A song by James A. Bland (1878) that was once Virginia’s state song, reflecting the persistence of racial stereotypes and the complex legacy of Black music in American culture.

namedEntities.name: Will Marion Cook
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Composer and musician
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He co-created 'Clorindy, or the Origin of the Cakewalk' and later explored African heritage in 'In Dahomey' and 'Abyssinia,' showing a commitment to Black self-representation.

namedEntities.name: Paul Laurence Dunbar
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Poet
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He collaborated with Will Marion Cook on 'Clorindy,' aiming to avoid white patterns of Black representation, highlighting the early efforts to create authentic Black narratives.

namedEntities.name: Clorindy, or the Origin of the Cakewalk
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Musical
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A 1898 Broadway show by Cook and Dunbar, intended to avoid white stereotypes, yet still reflected the prevailing racial tone of the time.

namedEntities.name: In Dahomey
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Musical
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A 1903 Broadway show by Will Marion Cook that explored emigration to Africa, representing a significant step in Black artists’ efforts to portray African heritage and identity.

namedEntities.name: Abyssinia
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Musical
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A 1906 Broadway show by Will Marion Cook that continued the theme of emigration to Africa, showing a sustained effort to create Black-centered narratives.

namedEntities.name: The Frogs
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Professional society
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Founded in 1908 by George Walker, it was one of the first Black-led professional organizations to fight exclusion from white-dominated entertainment unions.

namedEntities.name: Bert Williams
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Vaudeville performer and comedian
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A key figure in early Black vaudeville, he performed with George Walker and his wife Lottie Williams, and later took on roles in drag after George Walker’s death.

namedEntities.name: George Walker
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Vaudeville performer and leader
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He co-founded The Frogs and played a major role in advancing Black presence in American entertainment, with his wife Aida Overton Walker also becoming a significant figure.

namedEntities.name: Lottie Williams
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Comedian and performer
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: George Walker’s wife, she performed with him and later took on roles in drag after his death, showing the intergenerational and collaborative nature of Black performance.

namedEntities.name: Aida Overton Walker
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Performer and stage manager
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She took over some roles in drag after George Walker’s death, continuing his legacy and contributing to the evolution of Black performance in theater.

namedEntities.name: Sissieretta Jones
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Opera singer
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Dubbed the 'Black Patti,' she became a star in Europe but was paid less than white performers in the U.S., leading her to found her own troupe to assert professional independence.

namedEntities.name: James Reese Europe
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Composer and bandleader
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Called the 'Martin Luther King of Music,' he founded the Clef Club in 1910 and led performances at Carnegie Hall, helping establish Black musicians' professional presence.

namedEntities.name: Clef Club
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Professional society for musicians
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Founded by James Reese Europe in 1910, it helped Black musicians gain recognition, fair pay, and professional autonomy in the entertainment industry.

namedEntities.name: The Castle Walk
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Dance tune
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A catchy tune by James Reese Europe that became popular on Broadway, symbolizing the cultural influence of Black music on mainstream American theater.

namedEntities.name: Porgy and Bess
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Opera
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A 1935 opera about Black characters written by white composers, which has since provided opportunities for Black performers but is also controversial for its origins and lack of Black authorship.

namedEntities.name: The Hot Mikado
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Musical
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A 1939 Black version of a Gilbert and Sullivan operetta, starring Bill Robinson and featuring Rosetta LeNoire, showing Black reinterpretations of classic stories.

namedEntities.name: Rosetta LeNoire
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Dancer and performer
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She performed in 'The Hot Mikado' and later founded Amas Musical Theater in 1968 to promote multiethnic casting and inclusive Black musical theater.

namedEntities.name: Amas Musical Theater
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Theater company
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Founded by Rosetta LeNoire in 1968, it helped nurture new Black musical hits like 'Mama, I Want to Sing!' and 'Bubbling Brown Sugar,' advancing inclusive casting and artistic innovation.

namedEntities.name: The Wiz
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Musical
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A 1975 musical that reimagined 'The Wizard of Oz' through a Black lens, showing how Black artists have historically reframed stories originally written about others.

namedEntities.name: New York Public Library for the Performing Arts
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Museum and exhibition venue
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It hosted the exhibition 'Syncopated Stages: Black Disruptions to the Great White Way,' which highlights the history and significance of Black contributions to American musical theater.

namedEntities.name: Michael Dinwiddie
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Historian and curator
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He curated the 'Syncopated Stages' exhibition, emphasizing the fight for professional dignity among Black artists throughout history.

namedEntities.name: Hamilton
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Musical
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A modern Broadway musical that is seen as part of a broader lineage of Black musical theater innovations, reflecting the lasting influence of Black artistic traditions.

namedEntities.name: The Lion King
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Musical
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A major modern musical that is recognized as part of the evolution of American musical theater, influenced by earlier Black musical traditions and innovations.

namedEntities.name: Bring in ’Da Noise, Bring in ’Da Funk
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Musical
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A 1996 musical by George C. Wolfe that explores the 'regenerative power of rhythm' in Black history, and which directly engages with the theme of Black cultural self-creation.

importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The year when Noble Sissle and Eubie Blake met Flournoy Miller and Aubrey Lyles at a benefit for the N.A.A.C.P., leading to the creation of the groundbreaking musical 'Shuffle Along'.
The year when 'Shuffle Along' premiered, marking a pivotal moment in Black musical theater history with its all-Black creative team, company, and orchestra.

The year when the African Grove theater in Greenwich Village staged an 1821 production of 'Richard III' starring James Hewlett, indicating the early presence of Black artists performing for Black audiences before full abolition.
The year when the Hyers Sisters launched their first musical drama, 'Out of Bondage,' which is considered a foundational work in the emergence of American musical theater as a distinct genre.
The year when James A. Bland composed 'Carry Me Back to Old Virginny,' a song that later became Virginia’s state song despite containing a racial slur.
The year when Will Marion Cook and Paul Laurence Dunbar premiered 'Clorindy, or the Origin of the Cakewalk,' a show attempting to avoid white patterns of Black representation.
The year when 'In Dahomey' premiered, exploring emigration to Africa and marking a significant step in Black artists' attempts to portray African heritage and identity on stage.
The year when 'Abyssinia' premiered, continuing the trend of Black theater exploring African diasporic themes and self-representation.
The year when George Walker founded The Frogs, a professional society for Black entertainers to counter exclusion from white-dominated entertainment unions.
The year when James Reese Europe founded the Clef Club, a Black professional society for musicians that helped establish Black artists' autonomy in the music industry.
The year when the Clef Club Orchestra began performing at Carnegie Hall, showcasing Black musical talent on a national stage and challenging racial barriers.
The year when 'Porgy and Bess' premiered, an opera about Black characters written by white people that has since become a significant, albeit contested, influence on Black musical theater.
The year when 'The Swing Mikado' and 'The Hot Mikado' — Black versions of Gilbert and Sullivan operettas — appeared on Broadway, showcasing Black reinterpretations of classic stories.
The year when Rosetta LeNoire founded Amas Musical Theater to promote multiethnic casting, influencing a new era of inclusive Black musical theater.
The year when 'The Wiz' premiered, reimagining the story of 'The Wizard of Oz' through a Black lens and marking a key moment in Black musical re-framing of stories originally written about others.
The year when the musical 'Shuffle Along' was re-staged with a subtitle highlighting its historical significance, reaffirming its role as a milestone in Black musical theater history.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from 1821 to 1921 marks the foundational years of Black musical theater, beginning with the African Grove theater and culminating in the success of 'Shuffle Along,' demonstrating a century-long tradition of Black artists creating, performing, and shaping American musical theater despite systemic racism.

The early 20th century saw the rise of key Black musical theater milestones, including 'In Dahomey,' 'Abyssinia,' and 'Porgy and Bess,' reflecting both the challenges and achievements of Black artists in asserting creative control and cultural identity.

The period from 1939 to 1975 reflects a transformation in Black musical theater, from early adaptations of European operettas to original reimaginings like 'The Wiz,' signaling a broader cultural shift toward Black ownership and representation of stories.

The period from 1968 to 2016 marks the emergence of inclusive and artistically ambitious Black musical theater, exemplified by the founding of Amas Musical Theater and the 2016 revival of 'Shuffle Along,' which reaffirmed the legacy and continuity of Black artistic innovation.

articles.content: # Black Musical Theater, 200 Years and Running Published: 2025-11-07T17:17:47-05:00 Black and white photo of performers on a stage in a crowded room. A collage of recent stage productions including “Hamilton,” “Dreamgirls,” “The Lion King” and the 2016 “Shuffle Along.” Many people think of the rise of Black musicals as a recent phenomenon. A collage of recent stage productions including “Hamilton,” “Dreamgirls,” “The Lion King” and the 2016 “Shuffle Along.” A collage of recent stage productions including “Hamilton,” “Dreamgirls,” “The Lion King” and the 2016 “Shuffle Along.” In the 2016 show “Shuffle Along,” subtitled “The Making of the Musical Sensation of 1921 and All That Followed,” the playwright and director George C. Wolfe argued … … that Black musical theater began on Broadway almost a century earlier. In 1920, the songwriting team of Noble Sissle and Eubie Blake met … … the comedy team of Flournoy Miller and Aubrey Lyles at a benefit for the N.A.A.C.P. Their “Shuffle Along,” about love and fraud in a fictional Dixieland, was the most successful early Broadway musical by an all-Black creative team, with an all-Black company and an all-Black orchestra. A publicity photo showing a group of women in large hats. The lighthearted romp earned $9 million — more than $160 million today. It kick-started the careers of Josephine Baker, Paul Robeson, Florence Mills and Adelaide Hall. An illustrated poster for “I’m Just Wild About Harry.” Its hit number, a jaunty fox trot called “I’m Just Wild About Harry,” was still popular enough 27 years later to make a successful theme song for Harry S. Truman’s presidential campaign. An illustrated poster for “I’m Just Wild About Harry.” But if “Shuffle Along” was a breakthrough, it was hardly the beginning of Black musical theater. For that you have to go back another 100 years. Among the more than 270 items in “Syncopated Stages: Black Disruptions to the Great White Way,” an exhibition running through Feb. 21 at the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts, is a scale model of a 300-seat Greenwich Village theater called the African Grove. In the early 1820s, even before the full abolition of slavery in New York State, it showcased the work of Black artists for mostly Black audiences. An 1821 production of “Richard III,” starring the company’s co-founder James Hewlett, was favorably reviewed in the white press for both its songs and its Shakespeare. Another member of the company, Ira Aldridge, soon became a noted classical actor — but only in Europe, where he achieved widespread acclaim performing before royalty in grand opera houses. That his success came mostly for “Moorish” roles, including his famous “Othello,” demonstrates the limitations under which even the most successful Black performers struggled. Yet the struggle is not itself the achievement. Is it possible to see through the conditions that shaped and stymied Black artists to the art itself? In a letter displayed in the exhibition, Wolfe puts his finger on the problem. A letter written by George C. Wolfe, with parts of the text highlighted. Responding to an early draft of “Bring in ’Da Noise, Bring in ’Da Funk,” the 1996 musical about what he calls the “regenerative power of rhythm” in Black history … A letter written by George C. Wolfe, with parts of the text highlighted. … he notes that viewing the subject through the lens of racism is “incredibly reductive.” A letter written by George C. Wolfe, with parts of the text highlighted. “It’s like a cure-all, when in doubt, whip out the ‘whitefolks’ and everybody understands everything,” he wrote in a fax to members of the production team. A letter written by George C. Wolfe, with parts of the text highlighted. “I’m not interested in this at all. It’s the difference between talking about slavery and instead talking about slave culture. One is about what white people did to black people — the other is about what black people did for themselves.” A portrait of Anna Madah Hyers and Emma Louise Hyers. Consider the Hyers Sisters. Anna Madah Hyers and Emma Louise Hyers were classically trained singers who as children performed in private homes and concert halls. After the Civil War, they and their father formed a touring theater company. Their first show, in 1876, was the musical drama “Out of Bondage,” about the sorrows of slavery and the joys of emancipation. That play, along with later Hyers productions like “The Underground Railway” and “Uncle Tom’s Cabin,” marked the beginning of American musical theater’s emergence as a distinct form from its predecessors. Among those predecessors was the minstrel show, which traded in offensive racial stereotypes. A poster for the Thatcher Primrose & West’s Minstrels show, Minstrel shows usually featured white performers — and even Black ones — in blackface. The sheet music for “Carry Me Back to Old Virginny.” With or without blackface, racial stereotypes and performative servility remained popular. Some Black artists, having little choice if they wanted to work, fed the demand. In “Carry Me Back to Old Virginny,” written by James A. Bland around 1878, a formerly enslaved man sings that there’s “no place on Earth do I love more sincerely” than the place “where I labored so hard for old Massa.” From 1940 to 1997, despite a racial slur in the lyric, it was Virginia’s state song. In 1898, the composer Will Marion Cook and the poet Paul Laurence Dunbar brought their musical “Clorindy, or the Origin of the Cakewalk” to Broadway, seeking (as Cook wrote) to “eschew white patterns” of Black representation. Even so, its songs, like “Darktown Is Out To-Night” and “Who Dat Say Chicken in Dis Crowd,” reflected the prevailing tone of the day. Ernest Hogan, the star of “Clorindy” and a popular composer himself, felt it was important to document the newly emergent Black musical styles. But he came to regret some of the songs he wrote or popularized, with lyrics that would seem shocking today. Whether they played to stereotypes or against them, or both, Black artists worked to achieve control over their careers. “Syncopated Stages,” curated by the historian Michael Dinwiddie, who died in July, highlights that fight for professional dignity. Born in Virginia in the late 1860s, the singer Sissieretta Jones, dubbed the “Black Patti” after the great Italian soprano Adelina Patti, became an opera star in Europe. But when she performed in the United States, Jones was paid far less than white singers. Around 1886 she founded her own troupe. In 1908, led by the vaudevillian George Walker, a group of Black entertainers formed a professional society called The Frogs, in part to counter their exclusion from racist entertainment unions like The White Rats. Their influence helped Black acts demand top billing in national bookings. Among them were Walker (right) and his comedy partner, Bert Williams, one of the most popular vaudeville acts of the period. Bob Cole and J. Rosamond Johnson starred in several of their own musicals. The bandleader and composer James Reese Europe was called “the Martin Luther King of Music.” Europe’s catchy dance tune “The Castle Walk” became the toast of (white) Broadway. In 1910, Europe founded the Clef Club, another Black professional society, this one for musicians. To help finance the society, Europe led performances of the Clef Club Orchestra in a series of concerts at Carnegie Hall starting in 1912. The Clef Club’s chorus was led by Will Marion Cook, the “Clorindy” composer and a classically trained violinist. While breaking down professional barriers, Cook and others were slowly changing the way musical theater presented Black characters and stories. Though performed partly in blackface, two of Cook’s later Broadway shows, “In Dahomey” (1903) … … and “Abyssinia” (1906), explored the possibility of emigration to Africa. These shows were the product of a tight-knit network of collaborations with like-minded artists, including Williams and Walker and their wives: Lottie Williams … … and Aida Overton Walker. Overton Walker, having met her future husband when they both appeared in Sissieretta Jones’s troupe, took over some of his roles, in drag, after his death. Cook’s wife, Abbie Mitchell, made her debut in “Clorindy” at 14, later appearing in the original productions of “Porgy and Bess” and “The Little Foxes.” “Porgy and Bess” (1935) is now a highly contested text: an opera about Black characters written by white people. Yet it has also provided opportunities for generations of Black musical theater artists, including the influential tap star John W. Bubbles. “Porgy and Bess” does not fit comfortably into Wolfe’s schema of “what black people did for themselves.” It borrows from Black life and Black music. But in musical theater, borrowing is a two-way street. “The Wiz,” in 1975, was in no way the first Black musical to reframe a story originally written about others. In 1939, “The Swing Mikado” and “The Hot Mikado” — Black versions of the Gilbert and Sullivan operetta — both appeared on Broadway. “The Hot Mikado” starred the great dancer Bill Robinson in the title role. One of the “three little maids from school” was a young performer named Rosetta LeNoire. In 1968, in the midst of a long career on Broadway — often playing maids, she noted — LeNoire founded Amas Musical Theater, partly to promote multiethnic casting. Amas would nurture some of the hits of a new era for Black musical theater, including “Mama, I Want to Sing!” and “Bubbling Brown Sugar.” By then, Black musical theater had been completely absorbed into American musical theater. The forms that have dominated Broadway since the 1940s trace their lineage not only to operettas and shtetls but also to gospel choirs, juke joints and jazz clubs. Performers from “Hot Feet” standing with arms raised. When you look at its staging of a number from the 1929 musical “Hot Feet” … … it’s hard not to see the staging of “Cabaret” on Broadway 40 years later. Members of the “Shuffle Along” cast all wearing big round hats. Or to see the 1975 “Chicago” in the 1921 “Shuffle Along.” Stage production image of the musical “Hamilton.” The world of kick lines, cakewalks and clarinet licks is in many ways the creation of Black artists. It was what they “did for themselves,” as Wolfe says. But once they had done it, it was for everyone.
